title: 114_hr4783
content: The Act titled "Commercializing on Small Business Innovation Act of 2016" extends termination dates for SBIR and STTR programs from 2017 to 2022. Administrative funding deadlines are also extended to 2022. Required expenditure amounts are specified. The Act extends termination dates for SBIR and STTR programs to 2022. Required expenditure amounts are specified for fiscal years 2018 to 2022. The Act extends termination dates for SBIR and STTR programs to 2022 and specifies required expenditure amounts for fiscal years 2018 to 2022, including incremental increases in percentages for each fiscal year. The Act extends termination dates for SBIR and STTR programs to 2022 and specifies required expenditure amounts for fiscal years 2018 to 2022, including incremental increases in percentages for each fiscal year. Reporting requirements are outlined in Section 4. The Small Business Act is amended to require annual reports to be submitted by December 31 of each year and not later than March 30 of each year to the Administrator. Reporting requirements are specified in various subsections of the Act. The Small Business Act is amended to require agencies to submit standardized reports by March 30 of each year to the Administrator. Reporting requirements are outlined in different subsections of the Act. The Small Business Act is amended to require agencies to submit standardized reports by specific deadlines each year. Reporting requirements are detailed in various subsections of the Act, with specific dates for submission. The Small Business Act now mandates that Federal agencies must submit reports to the Administrator detailing the use of funds allocated to them. Failure to submit a report will exempt the agency from receiving funds unless they submit a plan for timely reporting. SEC. 5. INDEXING AWARDS FOR INFLATION. Section 9 of the Small Business Act is amended to adjust awards for inflation in Phase I and Phase II of SBIR or STTR programs. Phase I awards may not exceed $150,000, and Phase II awards are also adjusted. Phase I awards for SBIR or STTR programs are capped at $150,000, while Phase II awards cannot exceed $1,000,000. The dollar amounts will be adjusted for inflation as per section 1908 of title 41, United States Code. SEC. 6 amends the Small Business Act to change authorization to a requirement for insertion incentives. SEC. 7 clarifies the eligibility of certain small businesses. The Small Business Act is amended to clarify the eligibility of certain small businesses for the SBIR and STTR programs within 180 days of the Commercializing on Small Business Innovation Act of 2016. Small business concerns described in subparagraphs (B), (C), and (D) of section 3(p)(3) are eligible for awards under the STTR program. SEC. 8. COMMERCIALIZATION ASSISTANCE PILOT PROGRAM. Section 9 of the Small Business Act is amended to include a Commercialization Assistance Pilot Program for eligible entities to receive a second sequential SBIR award. Covered agencies must implement this program within one year of the enactment of the Commercializing on Small Business Innovation Act of 2016, with a limit of 5 percent of total SBIR funds. The Commercialization Assistance Pilot Program limits agencies to using 5 percent of their SBIR budget and will terminate on September 30, 2022. Eligible entities must provide a matching amount from a third-party investor to receive an award under the program. Funding from ineligible sources cannot be used to meet the matching requirement. The Commercialization Assistance Pilot Program sets limitations on award size and timing, with awards distributed during the Phase II period. To qualify for a second sequential SBIR award, eligible entities must submit an application with required information and matching funding details. The funds awarded must be used appropriately. The Commercialization Assistance Pilot Program awards funds for research and development activities that accelerate commercialization. Recipients are selected based on the potential impact on commercializing research, technical feasibility, and improvements to the commercialization plan. The Commercialization Assistance Pilot Program evaluates the progress of small businesses in Phase II activities for additional funding and assesses the likelihood of third-party funding leading to commercial and societal benefits. An evaluation report is required to be submitted to relevant committees three years after the enactment of the Commercializing on Small Business Innovation Act of 2016. The evaluation report for the Commercialization Assistance Pilot Program includes a summary of activities, results achieved, commercialization rates, growth in employment and revenue, comparison of success with non-matching Phase II recipients, demographic information, funds used by participating agencies, and distribution of third-party funding. The evaluation report for the Commercialization Assistance Pilot Program includes analysis of program effectiveness, recommendations for improvement, and definitions for covered agency, eligible entity, and eligible third-party investor. The term 'eligible third-party investors' refers to small business concerns, venture capital firms, individual investors, non-SBIR government entities, or any combination thereof. Ineligible sources of funding include internal research funds, non-cash contributions, funding from entity owners or affiliates, and debt-based funding. SEC. 9. INCREASED UNDERSERVED POPULATION PARTICIPATION WAIVER REMOVED. Amendment to the Small Business Act to increase participation of States with historically low SBIR awards. Conforming amendment to remove waiver authority.
